journal-meta.journal-id: J Am Acad Orthop Surg Glob Res Rev
J Am Acad Orthop Surg Glob Res Rev

title-group.article-title: The Influence of Multiple Modifiable Risk Factors on 30-day Readmissions and 90-day Major Complications After a Total Hip and Knee Arthroplasty: An Analysis of a Large Claims Database

contrib-group.aff: From the University of Connecticut, Farmington, CT (Dr. Luong); the Harford Hospital's Bone and Joint Institute, Hartford, CT (Dr. Kostyun, Dr. Witmer, and Dr. Grady-Benson); and the Orthopedic Associates of Hartford, Hartford, CT (Dr. Witmer and Dr. Grady-Benson).

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright © 2025 The Authors. Published by Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. on behalf of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons.

license.license-p: This is an open access article distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivatives License 4.0 (CC BY-ND), which allows for redistribution, commercial and non-commercial, as long as it is passed along unchanged and in whole, with credit to the author

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Preoperative optimization of modifiable risk factors (MRFs) for arthroplasty patients is a critical aspect of predicting and improving postoperative outcomes. This study evaluates the correlation between seven MRFs and postoperative adverse outcomes after total hip arthroplasty (THA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A retrospective review of primary TKA and THA were identified from a large medical claims database. Patients were categorized based on the number of MRF diagnoses present before surgery (anemia, malnutrition, obesity, opioid abuse/dependence, mental illness, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and tobacco use), from zero to seven. Adverse outcomes evaluated were surgical site infections (SSIs), venous thromboembolic events (VTEs), and readmissions.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Of the patient records queried (THA = 303,857; TKA = 692,157), two or more MRFs were identified in 41% of THA patients and 47% of TKA patients. Patients with two or more MRFs were at an increased odds of developing an SSI, and patients with three or more MRFs had increase odds of having a 30-day hospital readmission.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: This study adds to the compendium of literature, which promotes preoperative optimization of MRFs in arthroplasty patients to decrease the risks of 90-day postoperative complications.

body.p: There are more than half a million total hip (THA) and close to one million knee arthroplasties (TKA) being performed in the United States each year.1,2 Developing preoperative risk stratification tools for patients preparing for hip and knee arthroplasty is a necessary aspect of promoting patient safety and minimizing the occurrence of postoperative complications. There are several, well-known, preexisting, medical comorbidities and lifestyle activities that have the potential to increase the risk of unwanted postoperative outcomes following hip and knee arthroplasty.3 These risk factors include obesity, anemia, malnutrition, diabetes, opioid use, tobacco use, and mood disorders, such as depression and anxiety.4 Many of these preexisting conditions have the potential to be controlled or reduced through treatment interventions. Optimizing these health conditions preoperatively may reduce undesirable outcomes and prevent postoperative complications.5

Patients with pain and physical dysfunction associated with end-stage osteoarthritis who are candidates for hip and knee arthroplasty are affected by a range of modifiable risk factors (MRF), such as obesity and/or being overweight,6 anemia,7 malnutrition,8 and diabetes mellitus.9 Furthermore, the prevalence of mental illnesses,10 poor psychological health,11 and unhealthy behaviors12,13 are emerging concerns in the total joint population. Optimization of these conditions through targeted treatments and interventions has been a primary focus of clinical care over the recent decade. Previous studies have shown associations between these modifiable risk factors with increased rates of surgical site infections (SSI), 14-16 unplanned hospital readmission within 30 days of discharge,17-19 and 90-day postoperative venous thromboembolic events (VTE).20,21 However, research on how these multiple modifiable factors interact and contribute to surgical outcomes in hip and knee arthroplasty patients remains sparse. Despite the growing awareness of MRFs and their negative effect on patient safety and clinical care following hip and knee arthroplasty, current research has focused on these factors as individual issues without an understanding of the potential cumulative effect of MRFs that exist in combination. As the rate of negative health conditions and behaviors increases among the United States population,22-25 it is important for the clinical care team to understand the prevalence of multiple MRFs among patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty, as well as how a combination of MRFs influences postoperative outcomes.

The purpose of this study was to analyze a large adjudicated medical claims database to further explore the effect that seven MRFs, alone and in combination, might have on postoperative adverse outcomes after a THA and TKA. We hypothesized that THA and TKA patients with any MRF would be more likely to experience a 30-day hospital readmission or develop either an SSI or VTE within 90 days postoperatively, compared with patients with no MRF. Second, we postulated that patients with a higher number of MRFs would have increased odds of developing these complications.

sec.title: Study Design and Database
sec.p: This was a retrospective study using PearlDiver (PearlDiver Technologies), a deidentified healthcare claims database. PearlDiver is a proprietary web-based research platform that uses adjudicated medical claims from a large repository of Commercial, Medicare, Medicaid, Government, and Cash payer types. This study was reviewed by the institutional review board and designated as exempt.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The study sample included patients who had undergone a TKA and THA procedure accessible within the orthopaedic portion of PearlDiver by querying records using Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes 27130 (arthroplasty acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic arthroplasty [total hip arthroplasty] with or without autograft or allograft) and 27447 (arthroplasty knee condyle and plateau; medial AND lateral compartments with or without patella resurfacing [total knee arthroplasty]). Patient records were filtered to include patients (1) between 40 and 84 years of age, (2) with a diagnosis of primary osteoarthritis, (3) the first instance of the procedure, and (4) active within the database for 90 days after surgery. Records were filtered a second time to exclude patients with a (1) history of proximal femur fracture or pathological femur fractures, (2) history of distal femur fractures or pathological fractures of the knee, and (3) revision TKA or THA procedures (Figure 1; see Supplemental Appendix 1, http://links.lww.com/JG9/A383). All procedures occurred from May 2010 to June 2020.

caption.p: Flowchart of included and excluded patients.

sec.title: Modifiable Risk Factors
sec.p: The study sample records were queried for a diagnosis of seven MRFs before arthroplasty. A preoperative diagnosis of (1) obesity, (2) type 2 diabetes mellitus without complications, (3) tobacco use, (4) anemia, (5) malnutrition, (6) opioid abuse or dependence, and (7) mental illness was identified using PearlDiver's built-in comorbidity buckets consisting of International Classification of Diseases (ICD) version-9 and -10 codes (see Supplemental Appendix 2, http://links.lww.com/JG9/A384). Obesity was defined as any code stating obesity or complications due to obesity. Type 2 diabetes mellitus was defined as any code “without complications” and excluded codes that contained “unspecified”, “specified”, and ‘other specified” complications. Tobacco use, nicotine dependence, chewing tobacco, and a personal history of tobacco use were used to define tobacco use. Anemia was defined as those coded for iron, vitamin, or other nutritional deficiency. Malnutrition was defined as caused by a measurable protein-calorie deficiency. Mental health disorders included patients coded for major depressive disorder, bipolar I and II disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, persistent dysthymic disorder, and cyclothymic disorder. ICD-9 and ICD-10 codes denoting partial or full remission of the MRF were excluded. Patients were then collated by the type and number of MRFs.

sec.title: Adverse Outcomes
sec.p: The primary end points for this study were 90-day diagnosis of SSIs or VTEs and 30-day hospital readmissions. ICD-9 and ICD-10 codes were used to identify these three notable postoperative THA and TKA adverse outcomes: (1) SSI within 90 days after surgery; (2) acute VTEs within 90 days after surgery, defined as any deep vein thrombosis in a lower extremity, or a pulmonary embolism; and (3) all-cause hospital readmission within 30 days of hospital discharge, queried using a coding feature within the PearlDiver platform's built-in “Admission” function (see Supplemental Appendix 3, http://links.lww.com/JG9/A385).

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: The demographics of the final sample, the prevalence of each MRF, and the number of MRFs per patient were assessed using descriptive statistics. Chi-square contingency statistics were used to examine the frequency of individual MRFs and each postoperation adverse outcome. MRFs that were associated with a postoperative adverse event were then analyzed using a multivariable logistic regression controlling for age, sex, and Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) score to obtain odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Age was dichotomized as 64 years and younger or 65 years and older. CCI scores were dichotomized as four and lower or five and higher. To examine the association of the number of MRFs with postoperative complications, multivariate logistic regression was used to compare the number of MRF groups (1-7) with those with no identified MRF. All results yielding P < 0.017 were deemed statistically significant to account for the multiple analyses done on the same data set. All statistical analyses were conducted using PearlDiver's native application: R Studio software version 3.6.1.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The query resulted in 692,157 TKA patients (69.5%) and 303,857 THA patients (30.5%). In total, 322,226 TKA patients (46.6%) and 125,071 THA patients (41.2%) were identified with two or more MRFs (Figure 2). Results are presented by joint arthroplasty type (THA or TKA) due to differences in demographic features (Table 1) and prevalence of MRFs (Table 2) between the two groups.

caption.p: Bar chart showing prevalence of preexisting modifiable risk factors (MRF) among total hip arthroplasty (THA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA) patients.
Demographics of Modifiable Risk Factors Among THA and TKA Patients

fn.p: THA = total hip arthroplasty, TKA = total knee arthroplasty, CCI = Charlson Comorbidity Index

caption.p: Prevalence of Modifiable Risk Factors Among THA and TKA Patients

fn.p: THA = total hip arthroplasty, TKA = total knee arthroplasty

sec.title: Ninety-Day Surgical Site Infections
sec.p: For THA patients, the rate of a 90-day SSI diagnosis was 1.1% (n = 3214). Chi-squared tests revealed that all MRF were associated with 90-day SSI diagnosis, with all associations remaining in the multivariate regression (Figure 3). Tobacco use (OR 1.2, 95% CI: 1.1-1.3) and opioid abuse/dependence (OR: 1.7, 95% CI: 1.38-2.12) had the lowest and highest odds, respectively. THA patients with two or more MRFs (Figure 4, A) were associated with increased odds of having an SSI diagnosed within 90 days of surgery.

caption.p: Graph showing adjusted odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of surgical site infection (SSI) within 90 days after hip and knee arthroplasty based on preexisting risk factor. Adjusted for sex, age, and Charlson Comorbidity Index. THA = total hip arthroplasty. TKA = total knee arthroplasty

Graph showing primary total hip arthroplasty (THA) and number of preexisting modifiable risk factors (MRF). Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals for sustaining (A) a surgical site infection (SSI) or (B) acute venous thromboembolism (VTE) within 90 days or (C) readmission within 30 days of primary THA based on the number of preexisting MRF. Reference group are patients without a presurgical diagnosis of anemia, malnutrition, mental disorder, obesity/overweight, opioid abuse, tobacco use, or type 2 diabetes mellitus.

sec.p: For TKA patients, the rate of 90-day SSI diagnosis was 1.1% (n = 7669). Chi-squared tests revealed all MRF were associated with 90-day SSI diagnosis, with all associations remaining in the multivariate regression (Figure 3). Obesity (OR: 1.16, 95% CI: 1.10-1.22) and opioid abuse/dependence (OR: 1.89, 95% CI: 1.64-2.18) had the lowest and highest odds, respectively. TKA patients with a single MRF had reduced odds of being diagnosed with an SSI, whereas TKA patients with three or more MRFs were associated with increased odds of having an SSI diagnosed within 90-days of surgery (Figure 5, A).

caption.p: Graph showing primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and number of preexisting modifiable risk factors (MFR). Odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals for sustaining (A) a surgical site infection (SSI) or (B) acute venous thromboembolism (VTE) within 90 days or (C) readmission within 30 days of primary TKA based on the number of preexisting MRF. Reference group are patients without a presurgical diagnosis of anemia, malnutrition, mental disorder, obesity/overweight, opioid abuse, tobacco use, or type 2 diabetes mellitus.

sec.title: Ninety-Day Acute Venous Thromboembolic Event
sec.p: For THA patients, the rate of acute VTE diagnoses was 1.1% (n = 3184). Chi-squared tests revealed that preexisting anemia (χ2 = 6.7, P = 0.009), mental health (χ2 = 9.8, P = 0.002), and type II diabetes (χ2 = 6.8, P = 0.009) were found to be associated with an acute VTE diagnosis. Multivariate regression analysis showed that THA patients with a prior diagnosis of mental illness had a reduced odds of having an acute VTE diagnosis within 90 days of surgery, with no other risk factors associated with acute VTE (Figure 6). THA patients with one MRF had reduced odds for being diagnosed with an acute VTE, whereas THA patients with four to six MFRs were associated with the increased odds of being diagnosed with an acute VTE (Figure 4, B).

caption.p: Graph showing adjusted odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of 90-day acute venous thromboembolism (VTE) after hip and knee arthroplasty. Adjusted for sex, age, and Charlson Comorbidity Index. THA – total hip arthroplasty. TKA – total knee arthroplasty.

sec.p: For TKA patients, the rate of acute VTE diagnoses was 1.5% (n = 10,097). Chi-square tests revealed pre-existing anemia (χ2 = 17.9, P < 0.001) and type II diabetes (χ2 = 18.6, P < 0.001) were found to be associated with an acute VTE diagnosis. Multivariate regression analysis showed that TKA patients with a prior diagnosis of anemia had an increased odds of acute VTE within 90 days of surgery (Figure 6). TKA patients with one MRF had reduced odds of being diagnosed with an acute VTE, whereas TKA patients with three to six MRFs were associated with increased odds of being diagnosed with an acute VTE (Figure 5, B).

sec.title: Thirty-Day Readmissions
sec.p: For THA patients, the rate of 30-day readmission was 5.3% (n = 16,044). Chi-square tests revealed that all MRF expect mental illness were associated with 30-day readmission. Figure 7 shows the results of the multivariate regression analysis, whereas patients with a presurgical diagnosis of obesity had a reduced odds of readmission (OR: 0.90, 95% CI: 0.86-0.93, P < 0.001) and those with a presurgical diagnosis of malnutrition had the highest odds of readmission (OR: 1.68, 95% CI:1.49-1.90, P < 0.001). THA patients with one MRF had reduced odds of readmission, whereas THA patients with three to six MRFs were associated with increased odds of being readmitted (Figure 4, C).

caption.p: Graph showing adjusted odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CI) of 30-day readmission after hip and knee arthroplasty. Adjusted for sex, age, and Charlson Comorbidity Index. THA – total hip arthroplasty. TKA – total knee arthroplasty.

sec.p: For TKA patients, the rate of 30-day readmission was 4.9% (n = 34,013). Chi-square tests revealed that all MRF expect obesity were associated with 30-day readmission. Figure 7 shows the results of the multivariate regression, whereas patients with a presurgical diagnosis of mental illness had the lowest odds of readmission (OR: 0.88, 95% CI: 0.86-0.90, P < 0.001) and patients with a presurgical diagnosis of anemia had the greatest odds of readmission (OR: 1.31, 95% CI: 1.27-1.36, P < 0.001). TKA patients with one or two MRF had reduced odds of readmission, whereas TKA patients with three or more MRFs were associated with increased odds of being readmitted (Figure 5, C).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study used a large, adjudicated, healthcare administrative database to further understand the influence of individual and multiple MRFs on adverse outcomes following a THA or TKA. The presence of two or more preexisting MRFs, which was found to exist in 41% of THA patients and 47% of TKA patients in this study, led to an increased risk of SSI, whereas three or more preexisting MRFs led to an increased odd of readmission. Accurate and diligent preoperative monitoring of MRFs in THA and TKA patients is a critical component of perioperative care and patient management. The findings of this study support this notion, as all seven MRFs analyzed in this study were found to increase the likelihood of adverse outcomes in the 90 days following joint arthroplasty. Furthermore, this study provides a novel exploration into the effect of a combination of MFRs on postoperative recovery.

Infection after THA and TKA is a devastating consequence for patients, resulting in notable morbidity, revision surgery, and occasionally mortality. 26 Antonelli and Chen27 summarized the negative effects of obesity, diabetes mellitus, anemia, malnutrition, tobacco use, and mental health disorders on the development of SSI among total joint arthroplasty patients. Among a cohort of patients undergoing TKA and THA at an urban academic hospital, all cases of infection were associated with patients who had a diagnosis of obesity or diabetes.16 In addition, the authors noted the high prevalence of anemia and malnutrition among patients. A predictive model developed by Everhart et al28 identified a body mass index of 50 kg/m2 or greater, diabetes mellitus, and tobacco abuse as independent modifiable risk factors for the development of SSI among patients undergoing lower extremity total joint arthroplasty. Our results confirm these findings and support the need for a better understanding of a patient's nutritional status and level of anemia within the context of the patient's body mass and treatment of insulin-dependent diabetes.15 Preexisting psychiatric conditions have been found to be risk factors for SSI among patients undergoing cervical spine fusion,29 bariatric surgery,30 and cesarean deliveries.31 However, many of these studies note that the underlying cause linking psychiatric conditions to SSI has not yet been determined. Future work investigating and quantifying the synergistic nature of obesity, diabetes, anemia, malnutrition, and mental illness may reveal potential pathways for preventive intervention against SSI in this population.

Reducing the rate of hospital readmissions is a goal shared by all healthcare facilities and federal agencies, given the negative effect on the patient, as well as the cost burden to institutions.32 One large retrospective review demonstrated that obesity, diabetes, and smoking were associated with increased readmission rates after TKA.33 Interestingly, our data suggest that the diagnosis of a psychiatric condition may not increase the likelihood of readmission for THA patients. This is consistent with a recent article published by Knapp et al where they found an association between mental health disorders and readmission rates after TKA, but not THA.34

There is scarce evidence demonstrating a clear association between any of the seven MRFs we evaluated and the development of an acute VTE after a hip or knee arthroplasty. Of the seven MRFs we assessed, obesity has the strongest association with the development of an acute VTE after a total joint arthroplasty in other reports.35 This contradicts our findings that obesity had no influence on VTE development after a hip and knee arthroplasty. Interestingly, Parvizi et al36 demonstrated that severe weight loss was associated with VTE development after a arthroplasty. They also demonstrated anemia to be associated with VTE development, which coincides with our findings for TKA patients. The use of antidepressant and first- and second-generation antipsychotics for the treatment of psychiatric conditions has been associated with an increased VTE risk among the general population. 37 Several authors have cautioned for the need to understand the total well being of a patient,38 and how a psychiatric condition may influence unhealthy behaviors39 and a sedentary lifestyle,40 as well as stress-driven pathophysiological changes.41 When examining the association of multiple MRFs, an increased risk was observed when 3 to 5 MRFs were present. The development of an acute VTE in hip and knee arthroplasty patients may be a complex interaction, depending more on the presence of multiple MRFS and the synergistic effect between MRFs rather than the presence of any one risk factor. For patients undergoing total joint arthroplasty, the act of having surgery paired with multiple MRF and the potential for low levels of physical activity and mobility during the perioperative period may create the optimal environment for a VTE.

Our findings demonstrate that multiple MRFs may have detrimental effects on postoperative adverse outcomes after hip and knee arthroplasty. This retrospective review also suggests that multiple MRFs in a single patient may have an additive or synergistic effect on the development of negative outcomes. To our knowledge, there is a paucity of data demonstrating the potential synergistic effect on adverse outcomes after hip and knee arthroplasty when multiple MRFs are present. It is important to note, however, that many of these MRFs do not exist in singularity. Obesity, for example, is often associated with diabetes and malnutrition.42 Anemia may coexist with malnutrition, and those who are malnourished may develop nutrition-deficiency anemia. In addition, there are data that show that patients with mental health disorders are more likely to use opioids.43 These associations further emphasize the importance of comprehensive preoperative health optimization.

Patients with a single MRF did not show the same risk for adverse outcomes after surgery as patients with multiple MRFs. This may suggest that current medical care aimed at preoperative optimization of a single MRF may be a more achievable goal compared with optimizing multiple MRFs within a single patient. We were limited in our ability to appropriately identify patients who were optimized before surgery. Despite the lack of data demonstrating the influence of preoperative optimization before surgery in our study, it stands to reason that optimized patients will have improved outcomes. This has been demonstrated in previous studies. Based on a systematic review by Johns et al, the use of preoperative optimization protocols for patients undergoing a lower extremity joint arthroplasty improved postoperative outcomes. 44 These protocols were associated with decreased SSIs, hospital LOS, cost of care, and readmission rates.44 In addition, Statz et al45 and Johnson et al46 compared outcomes between optimized and nonoptimized MRFs before arthroplasty and found that patients in the nonoptimized group had increased rates of postoperative infection, readmissions, and mortality. Interestingly, they found hypoalbuminemia to be the strongest risk factor. More than half of all patients undergoing hip and knee arthroplasty in our study had at least one MRF preoperatively. Thus, the preponderance of evidence supports the implementation of preoperative optimization protocols as the standard of care.

The findings of this study should be considered in light of the limitations of the database. First, the PearlDiver is an administrative data set based on billing and coding data and may be subject to potential coding errors and inconsistencies that are inherent to healthcare insurance records and submitted claims. For instance, some MRFs could have been missed or incorrectly coded. Our findings suggest that a malnutrition rate of 0.9% among the study cohort may be an underestimation, considering that a recent review suggested the prevalence of malnutrition in the community to be 6.1%.47 Malnutrition is an inclusive term to present poor nutrition regardless of body weight.48 Malnutrition can be clinically identified through the use of blood markers rather than a subjective assessment of caloric intake. However, these clinical attributes may not be appreciable in ICD coding. Second, the lack of specific clinical and laboratory data makes it impossible to determine whether an MRF was optimized before surgery. Nor does it illuminate the degree to which individual providers might have already attempted to optimize their patients' MRFs preoperatively or postoperatively. Thus, the analyses may be limited with respect to interventions done perioperatively and the subsequent influence on the presence or absence of an MRF. Furthermore, these data analysis did not demonstrate which specific combinations of MRFs had the strongest effect on each outcome. Although associations of MRFs to the specific adverse events are demonstrated, causality is not specifically delineated. Future work should explore the combinations of MRFs that may have varying influences on clinical outcomes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study reinforces the focus on the identification of MRFs before THA and TKA, with specific emphasis that multiple MRFs increase the likelihood of 90-day SSI, acute VTE, and all-cause 30-day readmissions. Interventions to address these MRFs may have the potential to reduce the burden of these postoperative complications on patients, their families, and the healthcare system.

fn.p: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
